author: Liturgist
body:
# Support Question
It appears that Write-Output in 5.1 output UTF-8, but 6.1 outputs something else.

```
$ od -Ax -tx1c  ps5.1.17763.315.txt
000000  ff  fe  61  00  0d  00  0a  00  62  00  0d  00  0a  00  63  00
       377 376   a  \0  \r  \0  \n  \0   b  \0  \r  \0  \n  \0   c  \0
000010  0d  00  0a  00
        \r  \0  \n  \0
000014
```

```
$ od -Ax -tx1c  ps6.1.1.txt
000000  61  0d  0a  62  0d  0a  63  0d  0a
         a  \r  \n   b  \r  \n   c  \r  \n
000009
```

These were created using Write-Output @('a','b','c')

Is 6.1 producing UTF-8 without BOM? 1252? 437? 8859-1? ???

comments.author: Jaykul
comments.body:
Write-Output has **no encoding**. It outputs OBJECTS to the pipeline.

If you redirect text to an app you get the `$OutputEncoding` and if you redirect to file with `>`  or `>>` or `Out-File` you get whatever you have in `$PSDefaultParameterValues['Out-File:Encoding']` ...

I believe that the default for all of the above was "Unicode" (A.K.A. utf-16) up through PS 5.1 but in was been changed to utf-8 with no "Preamble" (A.K.A. BOM) -- I'm not totally sure because on my system I've set it differently.

## You can control it by setting `$PSDefaultParameterValues['*:Encoding']`

In PowerShell 6 there's an option `utf8NoBOM` which is what it should be by default, but in PowerShell 5 there is only `utf8` (with the pseduo BOM). You could use `ascii` but it's obviously, you know, ascii

title: How can encoding of Write-Output be known and/or controlled?
